TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
 ERCP - At [**2169-9-23**] 07:05 PM
   proceedure finished at [**2084**]
   - gen [**Doctor First Name 91**] following w patient; pt under gen [**Doctor First Name 91**] attending
   - ERCP done overnight and stent placed in common bile duct
   - Renal consult called, will see pt [**9-24**] AM
   - cannot get pt to oxygenate well (pre- and post-ERCP), 86% O2sat even
   on Fi02 100%, PEEP increased to 20 and tried decreased to 12; pt in
   reverse trendelenberg, attempted alveolar recruitment maneuver,
   paralyzed pt w cyscuronium
   - esophageal balloon placed
   - afib w RVR w rate 120s with bursts into 150s-190s
   - LR boluses, vasopressin and levophed
   - repleted lots of Ca w calcium gluconate --> due to saponification, Ca
   keeps going down, so keep repleting (so that pressors can still work,
   etc)
   - albumin 5% given w LR over 2hrs
   - 2:30am: ventricular rates more frequently in 170s-190s, hitting 200s
   occasionally but occasionally comes back down to 110s on its own; gave
   IV lopressor 5mg push, pressures dropped to 70s systolic
   - levophed maxed, vasopressin continued, added phenylephrine
   - started amiodarone bolus + drip (hung at 0330)
   - started dilt drip b/c responded well to 5mg IV dilt-->  HR in 90s
   this AM
   Allergies:
   Indomethacin
   Unknown;

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:15.3/32.1/1.3, ALT / AST:62/78, Alk Phos / T
   Bili:43/6.9, Amylase / Lipase:1381/576, Differential-Neuts:74.5 %,
   Lymph:19.7 %, Mono:4.8 %, Eos:0.5 %, Fibrinogen:615 mg/dL, Lactic
   Acid:2.9 mmol/L, Albumin:2.6 g/dL, LDH:989 IU/L, Ca++:7.2 mg/dL,
   Mg++:2.2 mg/dL, PO4:6.3 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   55 yo male with pmh of htn and asthma trasnferred from an OSH for
   worsening gallstone pancreatitis complicated by hypoxia, hypotension,
   and acute renal failure.
   .
   # Hypercapneic and Hypoxic Respiratory failure:  Likely ARDS. The
   patient was intubated yesterday morning due to tachypnea and hypoxia in
   the setting of receiving many liters of IVF while oliguric.  Since
   transfer to [**Hospital1 5**] ICU, has had difficulty maintaining oxygenation,
   despite alveolar recruitment maneuvers, positioning of bed, very
   elevated PEEP, esophageal balloon pressures.  Slowly desaturating
   further into 80s%.  Lung compliance low, and peak pressures 35-40,
   which suggest stiff lungs. Has an associated respiratory acidosis.
   - push ETT in 2cm further
   - increase tidal volumes and increase peak pressures; goal to increase
   pH to 7.3 and stabilize
   - increase PEEP further
   - Check serial ABGs to assess ventilation.
   - Propofol and fentanyl prn for sedation.
   .
    # Hypotension/Septic Shock:  Not responsive to fluids.  Was on three
   pressors last night briefly but weaned off phenylephrine
was just
   needed in the setting of BP drop after IV metoprolol bolused.  CVP
   estimated to be about 5.
   - Levophed prn + vasopressin to maintain MAPs>65.
   - Will follow CVP and continue with aggressive IVF (LR) fluid repletion
   given 3rd spacing physiology with pancreatitis.
   - f/u  blood cultures, UA, and UCx
   - Zosyn, renally dosed due to concern for possible cholangitis +
   Vancomycin
   .
   # Acute renal failure:
   Cr  increased further from 4.2 to 5.2 and oliguric.  Likely  ATN but
   possibly has postrenal obstruction or other intrarenal causes such as
   AIN.  Renal consult this AM called.
   - f/u renal recs  b/c may need CVVH in the near future if he remains
   oliguric and his K continues to rise.
   - f/u urine lytes.
   - Trend Cr.
   - Renal US to rule out postrenal cause.
   - Renally dose medications and avoid nephrotoxins.
   # Gallstone pancreatitis:  CBD stone still in place.  CBD stent placed
   by ERCP fellow.  Likely will worsen 24hrs post procedure before he can
   get better b/c of transient bacteremia caused by procedure.  Have
   repleted calcium significantly overnight
   - replete calcium as necessary for continued drop due to
   saponification. Improving lipase and amylase.
   - f/u ERCP/GI recs
   - Will f/u surgery recs.
   - NPO with IVF
bolus as needed for pressures
   - Trend his LFTs and pancreatic enzymes
   .
   # Hyperglycemia:  The patient does not have known history of diabetes,
   however was found to have sugars in the 500's at the OSH so he likely
   had underlying type II diabetes.  He was weaned off the insulin gtt
   prior to transfer.  no documentation sent with the amount of insulin he
   received by insulin gtt at outside hospital
   - continue to check q6h fingersticks and cover with SSI.  Will add up
   his 24 hour requirements and start a long-acting [**Doctor Last Name **].
   .
   # Anemia: The patient's Hct stable at 38.  Guaiac + diarrhea.
   - Active type and screen.
   - Continue to trend.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia:  His platelets are 156 which is stable in last
   couple days. (platelets 202 at outside hospital admission)
   - Continue to trend.
   .
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   NPO
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2169-9-23**] 09:11 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2169-9-23**] 09:13 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2169-9-24**] 05:40 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: subq heparin
   Stress ulcer: ppi
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: full
   Disposition:

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the information as follows:

The patient is a 55-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis complicated by hypoxia, hypotension, and acute renal failure. He was intubated yesterday morning due to tachypnea and hypoxia. The patient has had difficulty maintaining oxygenation, despite various interventions, and is slowly desaturating further into the 80s%. He has an associated respiratory acidosis.

The patient's hemodynamic status is unstable, with hypotension and the need for multiple pressors. His renal function is impaired, with an increasing creatinine level and oliguria. He has a history of gallstone pancreatitis, with a CBD stone still in place. He has also developed hyperglycemia, anemia, and thrombocytopenia.

The patient is receiving various medications, including vasopressors, anticoagulants, and antibiotics. He is also receiving IV fluids, oxygen, and mechanical ventilation.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and further deterioration can lead to respiratory failure.
2. Septic shock: The patient's hypotension is not responsive to fluids, and he may be at risk for septic shock.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is increasing, and he may require renal replacement therapy.
4. Infection: The patient has a history of gallstone pancreatitis and may be at risk for infection.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may require insulin therapy and close monitoring.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may require blood transfusions and close monitoring.
7. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may require platelet transfusions and close monitoring.
8. Sepsis: The patient's multiple organ dysfunction may be indicative of sepsis.

The patient's condition is critical, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma, who was transferred to the ICU from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis complicated by hypoxia, hypotension, and acute renal failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and has difficulty maintaining oxygenation, with a SpO2 of 83% on FiO2 100%. He has been treated with alveolar recruitment maneuvers, positioning of the bed, and elevated PEEP, but continues to desaturate.
* Gallstone pancreatitis: The patient has a CBD stone still in place, and a CBD stent was placed by ERCP. He is at risk for transient bacteremia and worsening of his condition over the next 24 hours.
* Hypotension/Septic Shock: The patient is not responsive to fluids and has required multiple pressors to maintain MAPs >65. He is at risk for continued organ dysfunction and sepsis.
* Acute Renal Failure: The patient's Cr has increased to 5.2, and he is oliguric. He is at risk for continued renal dysfunction and may require CVVH in the near future.
* Hyperglycemia: The patient has a history of hyperglycemia, and his blood sugars have been in the 500's. He is at risk for continued hyperglycemia and may require insulin therapy.
* Anemia: The patient's Hct is stable at 38%, and he has guaiac-positive stool and diarrhea.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelets are 156, which is stable in the last couple of days.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

* Respiratory failure: Pneumonia, respiratory distress syndrome, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.
* Gallstone pancreatitis: Pancreatic necrosis, abscess formation, and sepsis.
* Hypotension/Septic Shock: Sepsis, multi-organ dysfunction, and death.
* Acute Renal Failure: Chronic kidney disease, end-stage renal disease, and death.
* Hyperglycemia: Diabetic ketoacidosis, hyperosmolar non-ketotic syndrome, and death.
* Anemia: Gastrointestinal bleeding, infection, and death.
* Thrombocytopenia: Bleeding, infection, and death.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Respiratory support: Continue to monitor and adjust the ventilator settings as needed.
* Gallstone pancreatitis: Continue to monitor for signs of worsening pancreatitis and sepsis, and consider further interventions such as ERCP or surgical exploration.
* Hypotension/Septic Shock: Continue to monitor and adjust the pressors and fluids as needed to maintain MAPs >65.
* Acute Renal Failure: Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and consider further interventions such as CVVH or renal replacement therapy.
* Hyperglycemia: Continue to monitor the patient's blood sugars and consider further interventions such as insulin therapy.
* Anemia: Continue to monitor the patient's Hct and consider further interventions such as blood transfusions.
* Thrombocytopenia: Continue to monitor the patient's platelet count and consider further interventions such as platelet transfusions.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and optimize his outcome.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma, who was transferred to the ICU from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis complicated by hypoxia, hypotension, and acute renal failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient has hypercapnic and hypoxic respiratory failure, likely due to ARDS, and is intubated. Despite aggressive ventilation and oxygenation, the patient's oxygen saturation is only 83%. The lung compliance is low, and peak pressures are high, suggesting stiff lungs. The patient has an associated respiratory acidosis.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has hypotension and is receiving multiple pressors, including levophed and vasopressin. The patient's central venous pressure (CVP) is estimated to be around 5, and the mean arterial pressure (MAP) is being maintained above 65.
* Renal: The patient has acute renal failure, with a creatinine level of 5.2 mg/dL and oliguria. The patient is likely experiencing acute tubular necrosis (ATN), but postrenal obstruction or other intrarenal causes are also possible.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has gallstone pancreatitis, with a CBD stone still in place. The patient underwent ERCP and stent placement, but the procedure may have caused transient bacteremia and worsening of the patient's condition.
* Hematological: The patient has anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 12.9 g/dL. The patient's platelet count is stable at 156,000/L.
* Endocrine: The patient has hyperglycemia, with a blood glucose level of over 500 mg/dL. The patient was previously receiving insulin, but this was discontinued prior to transfer to the ICU.

The patient's medical complications are:

* Hypercapnic and hypoxic respiratory failure
* Hypotension and septic shock
* Acute renal failure
* Gallstone pancreatitis
* Hyperglycemia
* Anemia
* Thrombocytopenia

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Aggressive ventilation and oxygenation
* Pressors to maintain MAP above 65
* Renal replacement therapy (RRT) to manage acute renal failure
* Antibiotics to treat potential cholangitis
* Pain management with propofol and fentanyl
* Close monitoring of blood glucose levels and insulin therapy as needed
* Trending of laboratory values, including creatinine, blood urea nitrogen (BUN), and electrolytes
* Renal ultrasound to rule out postrenal cause of acute renal failure

The patient's prognosis is guarded, and the patient remains critically ill.

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma who was transferred to the ICU from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. He was intubated due to tachypnea and hypoxia and has been receiving multiple liters of IV fluids. His respiratory status has improved with changes to his bed position and ventilator settings.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 100.7F, heart rate of 86 bpm, blood pressure of 121/64 mmHg, respiratory rate of 34 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 92%. He has a central venous pressure of 23 mmHg and a bladder pressure of 18 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 12.9 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 11.0 g/dL
* Platelet count: 107 K/uL
* Creatinine: 6.9 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 34 mg/dL
* Glucose: 389 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 2.0 mmol/L

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Hypoxic respiratory failure
* Septic shock
* Acute renal failure
* Atrial fibrillation
* Gallstone pancreatitis
* Hyperglycemia
* Anemia
* Thrombocytopenia

The patient's plan includes:

* Weaning of ventilator settings and monitoring of serial ABGs
* Continuing bed positioning and propofol and fentanyl for sedation
* Weaning of levophed and vasopressin to maintain mean arterial pressure >65 mmHg
* Monitoring of urine output and creatinine levels
* Renally dosing of medications and avoiding nephrotoxins
* Trending of liver function tests and pancreatic enzymes
* Monitoring of calcium levels and repletion as necessary
* Continuation of insulin gtt for hyperglycemia
* Active type and screen and transfusion if Hct < 25
* Trending of platelet count and no signs of active bleeding

Potential medical complications that can arise:

* Respiratory failure due to worsening ARDS
* Sepsis and septic shock due to persistent infection
* Acute kidney injury due to ongoing oliguria
* Atrial fibrillation and flutter due to electrolyte imbalance
* Gallstone pancreatitis with worsening symptoms
* Hyperglycemia and hypoglycemia due to insulin therapy
* Anemia and thrombocytopenia due to ongoing bleeding or bone marrow suppression
* Increased risk of bleeding due to thrombocytopenia and anticoagulation therapy
* Complications related to central venous catheter placement and management.

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma, who was transferred to the ICU from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis, septic shock, and hypoxic respiratory failure. He was intubated due to tachypnea and hypoxia and is currently on mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 21 cmH2O and FiO2 of 80%. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 86 bpm, blood pressure of 121/64 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 92%. His laboratory results show elevated levels of creatinine, bilirubin, and lipase, indicating acute renal failure, cholestasis, and pancreatitis. He is also experiencing hypotension, requiring vasopressor support, and has a platelet count of 107, indicating thrombocytopenia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's oxygenation status is still a concern, and he may require further adjustments to his ventilator settings to maintain adequate oxygenation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock is ongoing, and he is at risk for further organ dysfunction, including acute kidney injury and cardiac dysfunction.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is increasing, and he may require dialysis to manage his electrolyte imbalances and fluid overload.
4. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis is ongoing, and he may require continued medical management, including antibiotics and pain control, to manage his symptoms.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, and he may be at risk for bleeding, particularly if his platelet count continues to decline.
6. Hypotension: The patient's vasopressor support is ongoing, and he may require further adjustments to his vasopressor therapy to maintain adequate blood pressure.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose level is elevated, and he may require further management, including insulin therapy, to control his hyperglycemia.
8. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is low, and he may require transfusion support to manage his anemia.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's oxygenation status and adjust his ventilator settings as necessary.
2. Manage the patient's septic shock with ongoing vasopressor support and close monitoring of his vital signs.
3. Continue to manage the patient's acute kidney injury with fluid restriction and electrolyte management.
4. Continue to manage the patient's pancreatitis with antibiotics and pain control.
5. Monitor the patient's platelet count and consider transfusion support if necessary.
6. Continue to manage the patient's hypotension with ongoing vasopressor support and close monitoring of his vital signs.
7. Manage the patient's hyperglycemia with insulin therapy and close monitoring of his blood glucose level.
8. Consider transfusion support for the patient's anemia if necessary.

   On this day I examined the patient and reviewed his hospital course to

s on the patient
s vent settings.  I have also reviewed Dr
   [**Last Name (STitle) 9271**]
s note above. I agree with her findings and plan of care.  Mr
   [**Known lastname 9314**] remains very critically ill with sepsis from cholangitis,
   pancreatitis, ARDS, hypotension, renal failure, and intrabdominal
   hypertension.
   Regarding his ARDS, he
s some better with rotating bed which seems to

   the less he
s tenous, on PEEP of 20 or more, 100% Fi02, and barely
   adequate sats and P02.  His lungs are stiff, and opacified.  Esophageal
   balloon pressured are not exactly making sense as they calculate to a
   TPP at inspiration that
s very small or negative.  TPP at end
   exhalation also neg. For now we
ll keep PEEP at 20 and be sure he
   tanked up.  Unfortunately if we use esoph press as indicator of Ppl
   then his corrected CVP is neg!  Hence for now we
ll correct CVP for
   PEEP (assume 25% of PEEP transmitted to pleural space pressure).  Thus
   his corrected CVP is 23-5 = 18 which is about where we
d want him.
   Unfortunately he
s still needing pressors though for now he
s not
   acidotic and lactate is surprisingly normal, suggesting his abdominal
   pressures are not causing gut ischemia.  Yet his abdomen is very large
   and tense with bladder pressures of 18-20.  I would appreciate surgery
   coming by and commenting on what criteria they
d use for surgical
   decompression. I would also seek their advice on how to decompress pt
   abdomen non surgically  (another trial of colonic airl decompression
   via catheter or c
scope?)
   Femoral HD line is in place though for now I think we have to be
   careful about removing any fluid via CVVH and he doesn
t need HD for
   electrolyte imbalance.
   His pancreatitis by amylase/lipase is subsiding, though he
s needed
   lots of calcium.  His WBC suggests his cholangitis is resolving as
   well.  He has a central line placed in OSH but right now it
s too risky
   to replace this line.
   His sister has been visiting and his attorney/proxy has made the
   patient DNR, not unreasonable given the current acuity and multiplicity
   of his problems.

   Assessment and Plan
   55 yo male with pmh of htn and asthma trasnferred from an OSH for
   worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock complicated by
   hypoxic respiratory failure and oliguric acute renal failure.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure:  ARDS likely as p/f ratio is 84 this AM.
   The patient was intubated Saturday morning due to tachypnea and hypoxia
   in the setting of receiving many liters of IVF while oliguric.
   Initially, had difficulty maintaining oxygenation, despite alveolar
   recruitment maneuvers, positioning of bed, very elevated PEEP,
   esophageal balloon pressures.  Change of bed with 35 degree tilting
   appeared to help oxygenation as his vent settings have decreased.
   - Attempt to wean down vent settings as patient can
   - Check serial ABGs to assess ventilation.
   - Propofol and fentanyl prn for sedation.
   - Continue bed positioning
   .
    # Hypotension/Septic Shock:  Intermittent fluid boluses are not clear
   if helpful as difficult to assess volume status.  Was intially on three
   pressors; weaned off phenylephrine and levophed dose is decreasing as
   well. Also with new fever spike while on broad spectrum antibiotics.
   - Continue to wean levophed + vasopressin to maintain MAPs>65.
   - Will follow change in CVP and attempts to continue with IVF
   resusciation given 3rd spacing physiology with pancreatitis, but to be
   careful with tenous respiratory status
   - f/u  blood cultures, Ucx
s and sputum cultures
   - Zosyn, renally dosed due to concern for possible cholangitis +
   Vancomycin renally dosed
   .
   # Acute renal failure:
   Cr  increased further from 5.9 to 6.9 this AM.  Likely  ATN highest on
   differential at this point.
   - Patient s/p IR HD femoral line placement
   - Contact renal  b/c may likely need CVVH today as patient is getting
   fluids and not urinating
   - f/u urine lytes: Fe Urea: 9.43%; likely pre-renal state
   - Trend Cr.
   - Renally dose medications and avoid nephrotoxins.
   - Follow bladder pressures and lactate
if continuing to increase
   consider calling surgery for possible decompression of compartment
   syndrome
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient on amio and dilt gtt to control HR.
   Patient with adequately controlled rate on these two medications.
   -  Stop dilt gtt today as patient as heart rate is well controlled
   -  Continue amio gtt
   - Goal to keep patient
s HR < 120 as to improve CO and perfusion
   # Gallstone pancreatitis:  CBD stone still in place.  CBD stent placed
   by ERCP fellow.  Likely will worsen 24hrs post procedure before he can
   get better b/c of transient bacteremia caused by procedure.  Have
   repleted calcium significantly overnight
   - replete calcium as necessary for continued drop due to
   saponification. Improving lipase and amylase.
   - f/u ERCP/GI recs
   - Will f/u surgery recs.
   - NPO with IVF
bolus as needed for pressures
   - Trend his LFTs and pancreatic enzymes
   .
   # Hyperglycemia:  The patient does not have known history of diabetes,
   however was found to have sugars in the 500's at the OSH so he likely
   had underlying type II diabetes.  Controlled on an insulin gtt.
   - Continue insulin gtt for now.
   .
   # Anemia: The patient's Hct decreased to 31.4.  Guaiac + diarrhea +
   fluids
   - Active type and screen.
   - Transfuse if Hct < 25
   - Continue to trend.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia:  His platelets are 107 from peak at 157 [**9-24**].
   (platelets 202 at outside hospital admission)
   - Continue to trend.
   - No signs of active bleeding
   - D/C sub q heparin
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO
   - d/w GI/[**Doctor First Name **] the idea of tube feeds, if not possible, will consult
   nutrition for TPN recs

   On this day I examined the patient and reviewed his hospital course to
   date. I have also gone over his labs, hemodynamics, imaging, and vent
   settings and status, and have spent considerable time at the bedside
   with RRT
s on the patient
s vent settings.  I have also reviewed Dr
   [**Last Name (STitle) 9271**]
s note above. I agree with her findings and plan of care.  Mr
   [**Known lastname 9314**] remains very critically ill with sepsis from cholangitis,
   pancreatitis, ARDS, hypotension, renal failure, and intrabdominal
   hypertension.
   Regarding his ARDS, he
s some better with rotating bed which seems to
   help decrease the effect of his tense abdomen on his vent status.  None
   the less he
s tenous, on PEEP of 20 or more, 100% Fi02, and barely
   adequate sats and P02.  His lungs are stiff, and opacified.  Esophageal
   balloon pressured are not exactly making sense as they calculate to a
   TPP at inspiration that
s very small or negative.  TPP at end
   exhalation also neg. For now we
ll keep PEEP at 20 and be sure he
   tanked up.  Unfortunately if we use esoph press as indicator of Ppl
   then his corrected CVP is neg!  Hence for now we
ll correct CVP for
   PEEP (assume 25% of PEEP transmitted to pleural space pressure).  Thus
   his corrected CVP is 23-5 = 18 which is about where we
d want him.
   Unfortunately he
s still needing pressors though for now he
s not
   acidotic and lactate is surprisingly normal, suggesting his abdominal
   pressures are not causing gut ischemia.  Yet his abdomen is very large
   and tense with bladder pressures of 18-20.  I would appreciate surgery
   coming by and commenting on what criteria they
d use for surgical
   decompression. I would also seek their advice on how to decompress pt
   abdomen non surgically  (another trial of colonic airl decompression
   via catheter or c
scope?)
   Femoral HD line is in place though for now I think we have to be
   careful about removing any fluid via CVVH and he doesn
t need HD for
   electrolyte imbalance.
   His pancreatitis by amylase/lipase is subsiding, though he
s needed
   lots of calcium.  His WBC suggests his cholangitis is resolving as
   well.  He has a central line placed in OSH but right now it
s too risky
   to replace this line.
   His sister has been visiting and his attorney/proxy has made the
   patient DNR, not unreasonable given the current acuity and multiplicity
   of his problems.

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma who was transferred to the ICU from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis, septic shock, and hypoxic respiratory failure. He was intubated due to tachypnea and hypoxia, and his initial oxygenation was difficult to maintain. He was placed on a bed with a 35-degree tilt, which improved his oxygenation. He has been receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics, vasopressors, and insulin for hyperglycemia.

Current status:

* Respiratory: He is on a ventilator with a PEEP of 21 cmH2O and FiO2 of 80%. His ABG shows a p/f ratio of 84, indicating ARDS.
* Cardiovascular: He is hypertensive and has a MAP of 65 mmHg, requiring vasopressors. His CVP is 23 mmHg, and his bladder pressure is 18 mmHg.
* Renal: He has acute renal failure with a creatinine level of 6.9 mg/dL, and his urine output is oliguric.
* Gastrointestinal: He has gallstone pancreatitis with a CBD stone still in place. He has been repleted with calcium, and his lipase and amylase levels are improving.
* Hematological: He has anemia with a Hct of 31.4%, thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 107, and is on an insulin drip for hyperglycemia.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory: Prolonged ventilation, ventilator-associated pneumonia, and respiratory failure.
2. Cardiovascular: Hypotension, cardiac arrhythmias, and cardiac failure.
3. Renal: Acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, and electrolyte imbalance.
4. Gastrointestinal: Pancreatitis, cholangitis, and intestinal obstruction.
5. Hematological: Anemia, thrombocytopenia, and bleeding.
6. Infectious: Sepsis, septic shock, and multi-drug resistant infections.
7. Nutritional: Malnutrition, electrolyte imbalance, and fluid overload.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
2. Maintain cardiovascular stability with vasopressors and fluids.
3. Manage renal function with diuretics and electrolyte replacement.
4. Continue to treat pancreatitis and cholangitis with antibiotics and supportive care.
5. Monitor and manage anemia and thrombocytopenia with transfusions and medications.
6. Monitor for signs of sepsis and septic shock, and adjust treatment accordingly.
7. Consider non-surgical decompression of the patient's abdomen to reduce abdominal pressure.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's nutritional status and consider tube feeds or total parenteral nutrition if necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 71-inch, 132.8 kg male admitted to the ICU with atrial fibrillation, acute pancreatitis, acute renal failure, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient had a difficult time oxygenating, but repositioning and adjusting PEEP improved oxygenation. An ERCP was performed, and a CBD stent was placed. A new HD line was placed, and CVVH was started to try to remove fluid and improve oxygenation. The patient remains oliguric.

The patient is on multiple medications, including amiodarone, vasopressin, midazolam, insulin, and fentanyl. They are also receiving TPN without lipids and have a DNR/DNI code status.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.8C, heart rate of 92 bpm, and blood pressure of 106/55 mmHg. Their oxygen saturation is 95% on 100% FiO2. They have a respiratory rate of 32 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 95%.

The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, creatinine, and lactate dehydrogenase. Their liver enzymes are also elevated, with an ALT of 196 U/L and an AST of 279 U/L.

Potential medical complications:

1. Abdominal compartment syndrome: The patient's bladder pressure is elevated, and they are at risk for abdominal compartment syndrome.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS may lead to respiratory failure if not managed properly.
3. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may progress to chronic renal failure if not managed properly.
4. Pancreatitis: The patient's acute pancreatitis may lead to pancreatic necrosis, sepsis, and multi-organ failure if not managed properly.
5. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and elevated liver enzymes may indicate an infection, which could lead to sepsis and multi-organ failure if not managed properly.
6. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure, stroke, or cardiac arrest if not managed properly.
7. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's TPN without lipids may lead to nutritional deficiencies if not managed properly.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's pancreatitis and respiratory failure may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain if not managed properly.

   55 yo male with pmh of htn and asthma trasnferred from an OSH for

   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure:  ARDS likely as p/f ratio is 84 this AM.
   The patient was intubated Saturday morning due to tachypnea and hypoxia
   in the setting of receiving many liters of IVF while oliguric.
   Initially, had difficulty maintaining oxygenation, despite alveolar
   recruitment maneuvers, positioning of bed, very elevated PEEP,
   esophageal balloon pressures.  Change of bed with 35 degree tilting
   appeared to help oxygenation as his vent settings have decreased.
   - Attempt to wean down vent settings as patient can
   - Check serial ABGs to assess ventilation.
   - Propofol and fentanyl prn for sedation.
   - Continue bed positioning
   .
    # Hypotension/Septic Shock:  Intermittent fluid boluses are not clear
   if helpful as difficult to assess volume status.  Was intially on three
   pressors; weaned off phenylephrine and levophed dose is decreasing as
   well. Also with new fever spike while on broad spectrum antibiotics.
   - Continue to wean levophed + vasopressin to maintain MAPs>65.
   - Will follow change in CVP and attempts to continue with IVF
   resusciation given 3rd spacing physiology with pancreatitis, but to be
   careful with tenous respiratory status
   - f/u  blood cultures, Ucx
s and sputum cultures
   - Zosyn, renally dosed due to concern for possible cholangitis +
   Vancomycin renally dosed
   .
   # Acute renal failure:
   Cr  increased further from 6.9 to 7.2 this AM.  Likely  ATN highest on
   differential at this point. Started CVVH yesterday afternoon
   - Continue CVVH to get fluids off
   - f/u urine lytes: Fe Urea: 9.43%; likely pre-renal state
   - Trend Cr.
   - Renally dose medications and avoid nephrotoxins.
   - Follow bladder pressures and lactate
if continuing to increase
   consider calling surgery for possible decompression of compartment
   syndrome
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient on amio and dilt gtt to control HR.
   Patient with adequately controlled rate on these two medications.
   -  Stop dilt gtt today as patient as heart rate is well controlled
   -  Continue amio gtt
   - Goal to keep patient
s HR < 120 as to improve CO and perfusion
   # Gallstone pancreatitis:  CBD stone still in place.  CBD stent placed
   by ERCP fellow.  Likely will worsen 24hrs post procedure before he can
   get better b/c of transient bacteremia caused by procedure.  Have
   repleted calcium significantly overnight
   - replete calcium as necessary for continued drop due to
   saponification. Improving lipase and amylase.
   - f/u ERCP/GI recs
   - Will f/u surgery recs.
   - NPO with IVF
bolus as needed for pressures
   - Trend his LFTs and pancreatic enzymes
   .
   # Hyperglycemia:  The patient does not have known history of diabetes,
   however was found to have sugars in the 500's at the OSH so he likely
   had underlying type II diabetes.  Controlled on an insulin gtt.
   - Continue insulin gtt for now.
   .
   # Anemia: The patient's Hct decreased to 31.4.  Guaiac + diarrhea +
   fluids
   - Active type and screen.
   - Transfuse if Hct < 25
   - Continue to trend.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia:  His platelets are 107 from peak at 157 [**9-24**].

   - Continue to trend.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

* The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma, who was transferred to the ICU from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure.
* He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 26 cmH2O and FiO2 of 100%.
* His oxygenation is improving, but he remains oliguric, and his creatinine level has increased to 7.2 mg/dL.
* He has a CBD stent in place, which was placed by ERCP, and is at risk for developing cholangitis.
* He has a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently on amiodarone and diltiazem to control his heart rate.
* He has hyperglycemia and is being treated with an insulin drip.
* He has anemia, with a Hct of 31.3%, and thrombocytopenia, with a platelet count of 105 K/uL.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to worsening ARDS or inadequate ventilation
* Septic shock due to ongoing bacteremia or sepsis
* Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to ongoing oliguria and potential nephrotoxins
* Cholangitis or pancreatitis due to the CBD stent or gallstone pancreatitis
* Cardiac arrhythmias or heart failure due to atrial fibrillation or underlying cardiac disease
* Hyperglycemic crisis due to inadequate insulin therapy
* Anemia or bleeding due to ongoing gastrointestinal bleeding or platelet dysfunction
* Thrombocytopenia due to ongoing bleeding or platelet destruction

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continued mechanical ventilation with weaning attempts as tolerated
* Close monitoring of oxygenation, ventilation, and hemodynamics
* Serial ABGs to assess ventilation
* Propofol and fentanyl for sedation as needed
* Continue bed positioning to improve oxygenation
* Weaning of levophed and vasopressin to maintain MAPs >65
* Renally dosed medications to avoid nephrotoxins
* Trending of creatinine and urine lytes to assess renal function
* Follow-up with surgery for possible decompression of abdominal compartment syndrome
* Continue CVVH to remove fluids and improve oxygenation
* Monitoring of bladder pressures and lactate levels to assess for compartment syndrome
* Continue insulin drip for hyperglycemia
* Active type and screen for anemia
* Transfusion if Hct < 25
* Trending of platelet count and continued monitoring for bleeding or thrombocytopenia.

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma who was transferred to the ICU from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis, septic shock, and hypoxic respiratory failure. He was intubated due to tachypnea and hypoxia and is currently on mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 26 cmH2O and FiO2 of 100%. He has a CBD stent placed and is receiving CVVH for oliguric acute renal failure. His lab results show elevated CRP, lipase, and amylase levels, and he is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics. He is also receiving insulin for hyperglycemia and vasopressin for hypotension.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's ARDS is likely to worsen due to his prolonged mechanical ventilation and high PEEP. There is a risk of ventilator-associated lung injury (VALI) and barotrauma.
2. Septic Shock: The patient's septic shock is likely to persist due to his ongoing infection and hypotension. There is a risk of multi-organ failure, including renal failure, hepatic failure, and cardiac failure.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely to worsen due to his ongoing oliguria and high CRP levels. There is a risk of chronic kidney disease and end-stage renal disease.
4. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis is likely to worsen due to his ongoing inflammation and high lipase and amylase levels. There is a risk of pancreatic necrosis and abscess formation.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely to worsen due to his ongoing bleeding and low platelet count. There is a risk of bleeding complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding and intracranial bleeding.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia is likely to persist due to his ongoing insulin resistance and high glucose levels. There is a risk of diabetic ketoacidosis and hyperosmolar nonketotic syndrome.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely to worsen due to his ongoing bleeding and low Hct levels. There is a risk of cardiac failure and poor tissue oxygenation.
8. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing a nosocomial infection due to his prolonged hospitalization and immunocompromised state.
9. Multi-Organ Failure: The patient is at risk of developing multi-organ failure due to his ongoing septic shock, acute renal failure, and pancreatitis.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, it is essential to continue monitoring his vital signs, lab results, and clinical status closely and adjust his treatment plan accordingly.

   recruitment maneuvers, positioning of bed, very elevated PEEP,
   esophageal balloon pressures.  Change of bed with 35 degree tilting
   appeared to help oxygenation as his vent settings have decreased.

   - Continue bed positioning
   .

   pressors; weaned off phenylephrine and levophed dose is decreasing as
   well. Also with new fever spike while on broad spectrum antibiotics.
   - Continue to wean levophed + vasopressin to maintain MAPs>65.
   - Will follow change in CVP and attempts to continue with IVF
   resusciation given 3rd spacing physiology with pancreatitis, but to be
   careful with tenous respiratory status
   - f/u  blood cultures, Ucx
s and sputum cultures
   - Zosyn, renally dosed due to concern for possible cholangitis +
   Vancomycin renally dosed
   .

   differential at this point.

   - Contact renal  b/c may likely need CVVH today as patient is getting

   - Trend Cr.

if continuing to increase
   consider calling surgery for possible decompression of compartment
   syndrome
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient on amio and dilt gtt to control HR.

   -  Continue amio gtt
   - Goal to keep patient

   # Gallstone pancreatitis:  CBD stone still in place.  CBD stent placed

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma, who was transferred from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and on a ventilator with a P/F ratio of 84, indicating ARDS. He is receiving 100% FiO2 and has a PEEP of 26 cmH2O. The patient's oxygenation has improved with repositioning and the esophageal balloon.
* Cardiovascular: The patient is hypotensive and has a mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 55 mmHg. He is receiving vasopressin and is being weaned off levophed.
* Renal: The patient has oliguric acute renal failure with a creatinine level of 6.9 mg/dL. He is receiving continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) and has a foley catheter in place.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has gallstone pancreatitis with a CBD stone still in place. He has a CBD stent placed by ERCP and is receiving IV fluids and electrolyte replacement.
* Endocrine: The patient has hyperglycemia and is being treated with an insulin drip.
* Hematological: The patient has anemia with a hematocrit of 31.3% and thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 105 K/uL.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS can worsen, leading to further hypoxia and respiratory failure.
* Cardiovascular instability: The patient's hypotension can worsen, leading to further cardiac compromise.
* Renal failure: The patient's oliguric acute renal failure can progress to anuria, leading to further electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's gallstone pancreatitis can worsen, leading to further pancreatic enzyme elevation and potential pancreatic necrosis.
* Infection: The patient's septic shock can lead to further infection, including pneumonia, urinary tract infection, and bloodstream infection.
* Bleeding: The patient's thrombocytopenia can lead to bleeding complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding and intracranial hemorrhage.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Ventilator support and weaning
* Cardiovascular support with vasopressin and levophed
* Renal support with CVVH
* Gastrointestinal support with IV fluids and electrolyte replacement
* Endocrine support with insulin drip
* Hematological support with transfusion of blood products as needed
* Antibiotic therapy for sepsis
* Surgical consultation for potential decompression of abdominal compartment syndrome

The patient's code status is DNR/DNI, and his disposition is ICU.

   Assessment and Plan
   55 yo male with pmh of htn and asthma trasnferred from an OSH for
   worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock complicated by
   hypoxic respiratory failure and oliguric acute renal failure.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure:  ARDS likely as p/f ratio consistently
   in 80s. Has had difficulty maintaining oxygenation, despite alveolar
   recruitment maneuvers, positioning of bed, very elevated PEEP,
   esophageal balloon pressures but recently stable in 90s % O2sat w 100%
   FiO2.  Change of bed with 35 degree tilting appeared to help but
   difficult to do accurate CVVH w bed tilted, so he is supine.
   - Keep PEEP at 26 (or higher) but do not want to derecruit alveoli
   - Decrease FiO2 and check ABGs to get paO2 in 60s for ARDS protocol
   - Midazolam and fentanyl prn for sedation
   - Continue bed positioning as tolerated to help improve increased
   perfusion to more ventilated areas
   .
    # Hypotension/Septic Shock:  Weaned off levophed this AM. Continues on
   Vasopressin.  Continues to be febrile
   - Cont vasopressin to maintain MAPs>65.
   - trend fever curve ; CVVH will bring temperatures down, so he may not
   be spiking fevers though he otherwise may have
   - culture if spikes through CVVH ; attempt PR Tylenol again
   - f/u  blood cultures, Ucx
s and sputum cultures (negative so far)
   - Zosyn, renally dosed due to concern for possible cholangitis +
   Vancomycin renally dosed
   - check again w OSH about cultures to see if still negative; can peel
   off Vancomycin if all still negative because we need to cover mostly Gm
   Negs from biliary system
   .
   # Acute renal failure:
   Cr  increased still very high but cannot monitor anymore because on
   CVVH.  Likely  ATN highest on differential at this point. Started CVVH
   yesterday afternoon
   - Continue CVVH to get fluids off
 increase rate from 50cc/hr to
   100cc/hr to see how he tolerates b/c BPs are better this AM
   - dose medications for CVVH
   - Follow bladder pressures and lactate
 if continuing to increase
   consider calling surgery to assess for possible decompression of
   compartment syndrome
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient on amio gtt in sinus rhythm. Dilt drip
   stopped yesterday
   -  Continue amio gtt for now for entire loading dose
   - Goal to keep patient
s HR < 120 as to improve CO and perfusion
   - cannot transition to PO amiodarone but need a way to maintain
   rhythm/rate in long-term once amio load complete
   # Gallstone pancreatitis:  CBD stent placed by ERCP fellow.  Improving
   lipase and amylase
   - f/u ERCP/GI recs
   - Will f/u surgery recs.
   - NPO with IVF
bolus as needed for pressures or give back fluid w CVVH

   .

   - Continue insulin gtt for now.
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma, admitted to the ICU with worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. He has been mechanically ventilated and has been receiving vasopressor support. He has had a CBD stent placed and is currently on CVVH for fluid removal. His labs show elevated WBC count, platelet count, and liver enzymes, and his electrolytes are abnormal.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's p/F ratio is consistently in the 80s, indicating ARDS. He has had difficulty maintaining oxygenation, despite alveolar recruitment maneuvers, positioning of bed, and elevated PEEP. He may require further intervention to improve oxygenation.
2. Septic Shock: The patient is still febrile and has a high white blood cell count, indicating ongoing sepsis. He may require further antibiotics and CVVH to manage his infection.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level is still very high, indicating ATN. He is receiving CVVH to remove excess fluids and may require further intervention to improve his renal function.
4. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient is currently in sinus rhythm, but may require further treatment to maintain a stable heart rate.
5. Gallstone Pancreatitis: The patient's lipase and amylase levels are improving, but he may require further treatment to manage his pancreatitis.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient has been found to have hyperglycemia and is receiving insulin therapy. He may require further treatment to manage his blood sugar levels.
7. Anemia: The patient's Hct level has decreased to 31, indicating anemia. He may require transfusion if his Hct level drops below 25.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is trending down slowly, indicating thrombocytopenia. He may require further treatment to manage his platelet count.
9. Abdominal Compartment Syndrome: The patient's bladder pressure is elevated, indicating possible abdominal compartment syndrome. He may require further intervention to decompress his abdominal cavity.
10. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require further intervention to improve his lung function.

These potential medical complications highlight the need for close monitoring and management of the patient's condition to prevent further complications and improve his outcome.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following:

The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of gallstone pancreatitis, acute respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, and hypotension. He is currently in the ICU, requiring mechanical ventilation, vasopressor support, and continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH). His condition is complicated by atrial fibrillation, pancreatitis, and septic shock.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 101.8F (38.8C)
* Heart rate: 90 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 114/55 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 29 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CVP 19 mmHg, CO/CI (Fick) 5.9 L/min, 2.5 L/min/m2

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 7.7 K/uL
* Hct: 31.3%
* Plt: 105 K/uL
* Cr: 8.4 mg/dL
* Glucose: 167 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.8 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.6 g/dL
* LDH: 960 IU/L
* Ca++: 7.4 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.2 mg/dL
* PO4: 4.0 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest X-ray: small volumes, bilateral effusion, and atelectasis, with some improvement in interstitial edema

The patient's microbiology results are pending, but no growth has been detected to date.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Atrial fibrillation: continue amiodarone infusion
* Pancreatitis: continue stent in place, enzymes trending down
* Renal failure: continue CVVH, attempt increased volume removal maintaining MAPs > 60
* Septic shock: wean pressors as able, remain on vasopressin, evaluate for abdominal compartment syndrome
* Hypotension: wean pressors as able, remain on vasopressin
* Fever: likely due to pancreatitis and cholangitis/gallbladder source
* Leukocytosis: likely due to pancreatitis
* Thrombocytopenia: low suspicion for HIT

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Worsening of respiratory failure and ARDS
* Progression of renal failure and need for dialysis
* Development of abdominal compartment syndrome
* Increased risk of bleeding due to thrombocytopenia and anticoagulation therapy
* Infection from pancreatic or gallbladder source
* Hyperglycemia and potential for diabetic ketoacidosis
* Hypocalcemia and potential for tetany
* Electrolyte imbalance and potential for arrhythmias

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with severe gallstone pancreatitis complicated by multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS), respiratory failure, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute kidney injury (AKI), and hypotension. The patient remains critically ill with multiple organ failures and a poor prognosis.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 101.8F (38.8C), heart rate of 90 beats per minute, blood pressure of 114/55 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 96%. He is receiving 100% fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) and has a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 26 cmH2O.

The patient's respiratory status is concerning, with ARDS and high PEEP requirements. His lung compliance is decreased, and he has a respiratory system compliance (RSBI) of 25 cmH2O/mL. His arterial blood gas (ABG) results show a pH of 7.35, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) of 40 mmHg, and partial pressure of oxygen (pO2) of 84 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 7.7 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin level of 10.8 g/dL, and platelet count of 105 x 10^9/L. His liver function tests (LFTs) are abnormal, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 279 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 196 IU/L. His blood glucose level is 167 mg/dL, and his creatinine level is 8.4 mg/dL.

The patient's imaging studies show small volumes, bilateral effusions, and atelectasis, with some improvement in interstitial edema.

The patient's primary issues include severe gallstone pancreatitis, respiratory failure, septic shock, hypotension, fevers, acute kidney injury, and hyperglycemia. The patient is receiving aggressive supportive care, including mechanical ventilation, vasopressor support, and antibiotics.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis-related organ failure: The patient's septic shock and MODS increase the risk of developing organ failure, including respiratory, cardiac, and renal failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS and high PEEP requirements increase the risk of respiratory failure, including ventilator-associated lung injury and respiratory acidosis.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's AKI increases the risk of chronic kidney disease and end-stage renal disease.
4. Pancreatitis-related complications: The patient's severe gallstone pancreatitis increases the risk of developing pancreatitis-related complications, including pancreatic necrosis, abscesses, and fistulas.
5. Infection-related complications: The patient's septic shock and MODS increase the risk of developing infection-related complications, including septicemia, pneumonia, and urinary tract infections.
6. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's septic shock and MODS increase the risk of developing cardiovascular complications, including cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac failure, and myocardial infarction.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's septic shock and MODS increase the risk of developing neurological complications, including encephalopathy, seizures, and stroke.

In summary, the patient is a critically ill 55-year-old male with severe gallstone pancreatitis complicated by MODS, respiratory failure, AKI, and hypotension. The patient requires aggressive supportive care, including mechanical ventilation, vasopressor support, and antibiotics. The patient's condition is associated with a high risk of developing multiple organ failures and poor prognosis.

   Assessment and Plan
   55 yo male with pmh of HTN and asthma trasnferred from an OSH for
   worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock complicated by
   hypoxic respiratory failure and oliguric acute renal failure currently
   on CVVH.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure:  ARDS likely as p/f ratio 120. Has had
   difficulty maintaining oxygenation, despite alveolar recruitment
   maneuvers, positioning of bed, very elevated PEEP, esophageal balloon
   pressures but recently stable in 90s % O2sat w 60% FiO2.  Change of bed
   with 35 degree tilting appeared to help but difficult to do accurate
   CVVH w bed tilted, so he is supine.
   - Concerning as PIP and Plateau pressures are quite high. ( C=P/V)
   Goals to increase compliance: decrease volume with CVVH; Decrease TV to
   400, and if possible decrease peep (unlikely able to decrease this as
   do not want to de-recruit alveoli any further)
   - Decrease FiO2 and check ABGs to get paO2 in 60s for ARDS protocol
   - Midazolam and fentanyl prn for sedation
   - Continue bed positioning as tolerated to help improve increased
   perfusion to more ventilated areas
   - Continue CVVH with as much volume to take off as can be tolerated to
   help improve oxygenation
   .
    # Hypotension/Septic Shock:  Weaned off levophed [**9-26**]. Vasopressin
   stopped overnight.  Continues to be febrile and now hypertensive off
   pressors.
   - No longer hypotensive; off pressors. Continue CVVH to increase volume
   removal and hopefully reduce bp some.
   - Consider anti-hypertensives if persistent SBP < 160
   - trend fever curve ; CVVH will bring temperatures down, so he may not
   be spiking fevers though he otherwise may have
   - culture if spikes through CVVH ; attempt PR Tylenol again
   - f/u  blood cultures, Ucx
s and sputum cultures (negative so far)
   - CXR today and if continues to spike consider abdominal CT to rule out
   other sources of possible infection
   - Zosyn, renally dosed due to concern for possible cholangitis; D/C
   Vancomycin as unlikely Gram positive source of infection
   .
   # Acute renal failure:  Cr  slowly coming down, but still very high and
   cannot monitor anymore because on CVVH.  Likely ATN highest on
   differential at this point. Started CVVH Monday afternoon [**9-25**];
   patient tolerating well.
   - Continue CVVH to get fluids off
 increase rate from 150cc/hr to
   150-250cc/hr to see how he tolerates b/c BPs are better this AM
   - dose medications for CVVH
   - Follow bladder pressures and lactate
 if continuing to increase
   consider calling surgery to assess for possible decompression of
   compartment syndrome
   - Renal following: will ask if lasix trial is suitable yet.
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient on amio gtt in sinus rhythm. Dilt drip
   stopped [**9-25**]
   - Continue amio gtt for now for entire loading dose as patient cannot
   take po
   - Goal to keep patient
s HR < 120 as to improve CO and perfusion
   - Keep track of Amio dosage; once 10 grams is achieved, may need to
   give maintenance dose through IV (200 mg/day)
   # Gallstone pancreatitis:  CBD stent placed by ERCP fellow.  Improving
   lipase and amylase
   - f/u ERCP/GI recs
   - Will f/u surgery recs.
   - NPO with IVF
bolus as needed for pressures or give back fluid w CVVH
   - Trend his LFTs and pancreatic enzymes
   .
   # Hyperglycemia:  The patient does not have known history of diabetes,
   however was found to have sugars in the 500's at the OSH so he likely
   had underlying type II diabetes.  Controlled on an insulin gtt.
   - Continue insulin gtt for now.
   - Consider Insulin in TPN and attempt to wean down insulin gtt
   .
   # Anemia: The patient's Hct decreased to 31 (from 52 at OSH when
   hemoconcentrated) but stable currently.  Guaiac + diarrhea + fluids
   - Active type and screen.
   - Transfuse if Hct < 25
   - Continue to trend.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia:  His platelets are trending down slowly.  Low
   suspicion for HIT, but HIT antibody sent, and subq heparin DCed
   yesterday.  [**Month (only) 8**] be secondary to Zosyn. (platelets 202 at outside
   hospital admission)
   - Continue to trend.

   55 yo male with pmh of HTN and asthma trasnferred from an OSH for
   worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock complicated by
   hypoxic respiratory failure and oliguric acute renal failure currently
   on CVVH.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure:  ARDS likely as p/f ratio 120. Has had
   difficulty maintaining oxygenation, despite alveolar recruitment
   maneuvers, positioning of bed, very elevated PEEP, esophageal balloon
   pressures but recently stable in 90s % O2sat w 60% FiO2.  Change of bed
   with 35 degree tilting appeared to help but difficult to do accurate
   CVVH w bed tilted, so he is supine.
   - Concerning as PIP and Plateau pressures are quite high. ( C=P/V)
   Goals to increase compliance: decrease volume with CVVH; Decrease TV to
   400, and if possible decrease peep (unlikely able to decrease this as
   do not want to de-recruit alveoli any further)
   - Decrease FiO2 and check ABGs to get paO2 in 60s for ARDS protocol
   - Midazolam and fentanyl prn for sedation
   - Continue bed positioning as tolerated to help improve increased
   perfusion to more ventilated areas
   - Continue CVVH with as much volume to take off as can be tolerated to
   help improve oxygenation
   .
    # Hypotension/Septic Shock:  Weaned off levophed [**9-26**]. Vasopressin
   stopped overnight.  Continues to be febrile and now hypertensive off
   pressors.
   - No longer hypotensive; off pressors. Continue CVVH to increase volume
   removal and hopefully reduce bp some.
   - Consider anti-hypertensives if persistent SBP < 160
   - trend fever curve ; CVVH will bring temperatures down, so he may not
   be spiking fevers though he otherwise may have
   - culture if spikes through CVVH ; attempt PR Tylenol again
   - f/u  blood cultures, Ucx
s and sputum cultures (negative so far)
   - CXR today and if continues to spike consider abdominal CT to rule out
   other sources of possible infection
   - Zosyn, renally dosed due to concern for possible cholangitis; D/C
   Vancomycin as unlikely Gram positive source of infection
   .
   # Acute renal failure:  Cr  slowly coming down, but still very high and
   cannot monitor anymore because on CVVH.  Likely ATN highest on
   differential at this point. Started CVVH Monday afternoon [**9-25**];
   patient tolerating well.
   - Continue CVVH to get fluids off
 increase rate from 150cc/hr to
   150-250cc/hr to see how he tolerates b/c BPs are better this AM
   - dose medications for CVVH
   - Follow bladder pressures and lactate
 if continuing to increase
   consider calling surgery to assess for possible decompression of
   compartment syndrome
   - Renal following: will ask if lasix trial is suitable yet.
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient on amio gtt in sinus rhythm. Dilt drip
   stopped [**9-25**]
   - Continue amio gtt for now for entire loading dose as patient cannot
   take po
   - Goal to keep patient
s HR < 120 as to improve CO and perfusion
   - Keep track of Amio dosage; once 10 grams is achieved, may need to
   give maintenance dose through IV (200 mg/day)
   # Gallstone pancreatitis:  CBD stent placed by ERCP fellow.  Improving
   lipase and amylase
   - f/u ERCP/GI recs
   - Will f/u surgery recs.
   - NPO with IVF
bolus as needed for pressures or give back fluid w CVVH
   - Trend his LFTs and pancreatic enzymes
   .
   # Hyperglycemia:  The patient does not have known history of diabetes,
   however was found to have sugars in the 500's at the OSH so he likely
   had underlying type II diabetes.  Controlled on an insulin gtt.
   - Continue insulin gtt for now.
   - Consider Insulin in TPN and attempt to wean down insulin gtt

   # Anemia: The patient's Hct decreased to 31 (from 52 at OSH when

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma, who was transferred from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis, septic shock, and hypoxic respiratory failure. He is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) and mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.6C (99.6F)
* Heart rate: 92 bpm
* Blood pressure: 163/66 mmHg (87/49 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 30 inspirations per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* PaO2/FiO2 ratio: 123

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 8.0 K/uL
* Hematocrit: 32.0%
* Platelet count: 102 K/uL
* Creatinine: 6.5 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 19 mEq/L
* Sodium: 137 mg/dL
* Potassium: 5.3 mEq/L
* Chloride: 102 mEq/L
* Calcium: 7.7 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.3 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.6 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Hypoxic respiratory failure
* Septic shock
* Acute renal failure
* Atrial fibrillation
* Gallstone pancreatitis
* Hyperglycemia
* Anemia
* Thrombocytopenia

The patient's medications include:

* Fentanyl (concentrate) 100 mcg/hour
* Insulin (regular) 9 units/hour
* Amiodarone 0.5 mg/min
* Midazolam (Versed) 7 mg/hour
* Pantoprazole (Protonix)
* Zosyn (piperacillin/tazobactam)
* Vancomycin
* CVVH

The patient's physical examination shows:

* Sedated and intubated
* Sclera icteric and scleral edema present
* Pupils small and equal; slightly reactive to slight
* Neck: supple, JVD difficult to assess
* Lungs: anteriorly slightly rhonchorous
* CV: rate 80s, regular rhythm, soft heart sounds
* Abdomen: no bowel sounds, very distended and tympanic
* GU: Foley present
* Ext: warm, well-perfused, pulses difficult to palpate but dopplerable, edematous extremities

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* Acute kidney injury
* Atrial fibrillation
* Gallstone pancreatitis
* Hyperglycemia
* Anemia
* Thrombocytopenia

The patient's goals include:

* To improve oxygenation and ventilation
* To manage septic shock and hypotension
* To improve renal function
* To manage atrial fibrillation
* To control hyperglycemia
* To manage anemia and thrombocytopenia
* To prevent and treat potential complications such as respiratory failure, sepsis, and acute kidney injury.

   Assessment and Plan
   55 yo male with pmh of HTN and asthma trasnferred from an OSH for
   worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock complicated by
   hypoxic respiratory failure and oliguric acute renal failure currently
   on CVVH.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure:  ARDS likely as p/f ratio 120. Has had
   difficulty maintaining oxygenation, despite alveolar recruitment
   maneuvers, positioning of bed, very elevated PEEP, esophageal balloon
   pressures but recently stable in 90s % O2sat w 60% FiO2.  Change of bed
   with 35 degree tilting appeared to help but difficult to do accurate
   CVVH w bed tilted, so he is supine.
   - Keep PEEP at 26 (or higher) but do not want to derecruit alveoli
   - Decrease FiO2 and check ABGs to get paO2 in 60s for ARDS protocol
   - Midazolam and fentanyl prn for sedation
   - Continue bed positioning as tolerated to help improve increased
   perfusion to more ventilated areas
   - Continue CVVH with as much volume to take off as can be tolerated to
   help improve oxygenation
   .
    # Hypotension/Septic Shock:  Weaned off levophed [**9-26**]. Vasopressin
   stopped overnight.  Continues to be febrile
   - Cont vasopressin to maintain MAPs>65.
   - trend fever curve ; CVVH will bring temperatures down, so he may not
   be spiking fevers though he otherwise may have
   - culture if spikes through CVVH ; attempt PR Tylenol again
   - f/u  blood cultures, Ucx
s and sputum cultures (negative so far)
   - Zosyn, renally dosed due to concern for possible cholangitis +
   Vancomycin renally dosed
   - check again w OSH about cultures to see if still negative; can peel
   off Vancomycin if all still negative because we need to cover mostly Gm
   Negs from biliary system
   .
   # Acute renal failure:
   Cr  increased still very high but cannot monitor anymore because on
   CVVH.  Likely  ATN highest on differential at this point. Started CVVH
   Monday afternoon [**9-25**]; patient tolerating well.
   - Continue CVVH to get fluids off
 increase rate from 150cc/hr to
   150-250cc/hr to see how he tolerates b/c BPs are better this AM
   - dose medications for CVVH
   - Follow bladder pressures and lactate
 if continuing to increase
   consider calling surgery to assess for possible decompression of
   compartment syndrome
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient on amio gtt in sinus rhythm. Dilt drip
   stopped [**9-25**]
   - Continue amio gtt for now for entire loading dose as patient cannot
   take po
   - Goal to keep patient
s HR < 120 as to improve CO and perfusion
   - Keep track of Amio dosage; once 10 grams is achieved, may need to
   give maintenance dose through IV (200 mg/day)
   # Gallstone pancreatitis:  CBD stent placed by ERCP fellow.  Improving
   lipase and amylase
   - f/u ERCP/GI recs
   - Will f/u surgery recs.
   - NPO with IVF
bolus as needed for pressures or give back fluid w CVVH
   - Trend his LFTs and pancreatic enzymes
   .
   # Hyperglycemia:  The patient does not have known history of diabetes,
   however was found to have sugars in the 500's at the OSH so he likely
   had underlying type II diabetes.  Controlled on an insulin gtt.
   - Continue insulin gtt for now.
   - Consider Insulin in TPN
   .
   # Anemia: The patient's Hct decreased to 31 (from 52 at OSH when
   hemoconcentrated) but stable currently.  Guaiac + diarrhea + fluids
   - Active type and screen.
   - Transfuse if Hct < 25
   - Continue to trend.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia:  His platelets are trending down slowly.  Low
   suspicion for HIT, but HIT antibody sent, and subq heparin DCed
   yesterday.  [**Month (only) 8**] be secondary to Zosyn. (platelets 202 at outside
   hospital admission)
   - Continue to trend.
   - No signs of active bleeding

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma who was transferred from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. He is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) and mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure of 163/66 mmHg, heart rate of 92 beats per minute, and respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 96% on a FiO2 of 60%.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels, indicating ongoing inflammation and tissue damage. His creatinine level is still elevated, consistent with acute renal failure.

The patient's medical conditions include:

1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient has difficulty maintaining oxygenation despite alveolar recruitment maneuvers, positioning, and elevated PEEP. The P/F ratio is 120, suggesting ARDS.
2. Septic shock: The patient was weaned off levophed and vasopressin was stopped overnight. He remains febrile and is being treated with vasopressin to maintain mean arterial pressure above 65 mmHg.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is still elevated, and he is on CVVH to remove excess fluids and waste products.
4. Atrial fibrillation: The patient is in sinus rhythm on amiodarone and has a goal heart rate of less than 120 beats per minute.
5. Gallstone pancreatitis: The patient has a CBD stent placed by ERCP fellow and is improving in terms of lipase and amylase levels.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient was found to have sugars in the 500's at the OSH and is being treated with an insulin infusion.
7. Anemia: The patient's Hct decreased to 31 from 52 at OSH, but is stable currently.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is trending down, and he has a low suspicion for HIT, but HIT antibody is being sent.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's P/F ratio is 120, indicating ARDS, which can progress to respiratory failure if not managed properly.
2. Septic shock: The patient's febrile state and ongoing inflammation can lead to further deterioration in his condition if not managed promptly.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is still elevated, and he is at risk of further kidney injury if not managed properly.
4. Bleeding complications: The patient's thrombocytopenia and ongoing inflammation can increase his risk of bleeding complications.
5. Infection: The patient's ongoing inflammation and febrile state can increase his risk of infection, particularly in the respiratory and urinary tracts.
6. Pancreatitis: The patient's gallstone pancreatitis can worsen if not managed properly, leading to further pancreatic damage and potentially life-threatening complications.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, it is recommended that he continue to receive close monitoring and management in the ICU, with a focus on optimizing his oxygenation, managing his septic shock, and preventing further complications.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with severe gallstone pancreatitis complicated by multiorgan dysfunction syndrome (MOSD). The patient remains critically ill with multiorgan failure, including respiratory failure, septic shock, hypotension, fevers, acute renal failure, and hyperglycemia.

The patient's primary issues include:

1. GS pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis is severe and has led to multiorgan dysfunction.
2. Respiratory failure/ARDS: The patient requires high levels of oxygen and PEEP to maintain adequate oxygenation.
3. Septic shock: The patient has septic shock, which is likely related to the pancreatitis and multiorgan dysfunction.
4. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, and he requires vasopressors to maintain adequate perfusion.
5. Fevers: The patient remains febrile, likely due to the pancreatitis and multiorgan dysfunction.
6. ARF: The patient has acute renal failure, which is likely related to the pancreatitis and septic shock.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient has hyperglycemia, which is likely related to the pancreatitis and multiorgan dysfunction.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has thrombocytopenia, which is likely related to the pancreatitis and septic shock.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 8.0
* Hct: 32.0
* Plt: 102
* Cr: 6.5
* TCO2: 21
* Glucose: 130
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 13.9/30.0/1.2, ALT/AST: 142/219, Alk Phos/T Bili: 48/8.6, Amylase/Lipase: 200/51, Differential-Neuts: 77.3%, Lymph: 16.7%, Mono: 4.6%, Eos: 1.2%, Fibrinogen: 615 mg/dL, Lactic Acid: 1.6 mmol/L, Albumin: 2.6 g/dL, LDH: 960 IU/L, Ca++: 7.4 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.3 mg/dL, PO4: 3.6 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show no new abnormalities.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Aggressive supportive care for GS pancreatitis and MODS.
2. Continue to wean FIO2 further following ABGs closely.
3. Maintain current level of PEEP at 26 cmH2O.
4. Continue to follow bladder pressures to monitor for abdominal compartment syndrome.
5. Repeat CXR and consider repeat abdominal imaging to monitor for infection.
6. Continue empiric vanco/zosyn for 4 days and then consider discontinuing.
7. Continue to monitor for and manage hyperglycemia and hyperkalemia.
8. Continue to monitor for and manage thrombocytopenia.
9. Continue to provide aggressive supportive care for respiratory failure.
10. Continue to monitor for and manage septic shock.

The patient's prognosis is poor, and he remains critically ill with multiorgan failure.

   Acid:1.6 mmol/L, Albumin:2.6 g/dL, LDH:960 IU/L, Ca++:7.4 mg/dL,

   55M with severe GS pancreatitis c/b MOSD.
   Primary issues remain:
          GS pancreatitis
          Resp failure/ARDS
          Septic shock
          hypotension
          fevers
          ARF
          hyperglycemia
          thrombocytopenia
   We are making slow progress with volume removal, able to come down on
   FIO2 with improvement in P:F ratio. Hemodynamics improving as well, now
   off pressors.
   Agree with plan to continue aggressive supportive care for GS
   pancreatitis and MODS.  While he remains very tenuous from resp
   standpoint with high peep in setting of ards and large distended abd we
   are making progress. Tran pl pressure is slightly neg at end exp, but
   will continue with current level of peep at this time given high plt
   pressures and improvement in pao2.  Airway pressures should improve
   further with additional volume removal.  Will also attempt further
   decrease in TV to help (already on 6cc/kg). If able to tolerate this
   change, well next wean fio2 further following abgs closely.
   We continue to follow his bladder pressures to monitor for abd
   compartment syndrome as his very distended abd is contributing to his
   high peep needs,  This should also improve with volume removal.
   He remains febrile but without leukocytosis. We continue to discuss
   potential infectious etiologies, though the most likely source of his
   continued temp is severe pancreatitis w/ inflammation.  Reassuring is
   his hemodynamic improvement and ability to wean off pressors. He is s/p
   ercp with CBD stone removal and stent and his enzymes and lfts are
   trending down.  Will d/c vanco today given no GPC in any cx
s and
   continue empiric zosyn day 5.  Although we note improvement clinically
   in O2 with volume off, given his continued temps will repeat cxr and
   consider repeat abd imaging though would be limited study given no IV
   contrast. His OSH lines have not been changed since transfer fiven his
   very tenuous status, and with no new growth from blood will hold on
   line changes at this time.
   He remains on cvvh and we will attempt increased volume removal as BP
   tolerates maintaining MAPS > 60.  We continue to renally dose meds and
   avoid nephrotoxins. We continue amio gtt for load, for prior rapid
   a-fib, and he remains in nsr. We have a low suspicion for HIT but
   suspect his thrombocytopenia is related to failed liver and sepsis.
   Counts remain stable.
   Pt remains very ill with multi organ failure and poor prognosis though
   we are seeing signs of slow improvement.  We continue to update his HCP
   and family.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   TPN without Lipids - [**2169-9-26**] 06:21 PM 45.[**Telephone/Fax (5) 1156**] mL/hour, if
   OG outpt is down will start trophic TFs.
